At-a-Glance: Reliable, attractive water sources keep bees off neighbour pools and support brood food production and hive cooling.
Why it Matters: Water is essential for brood food dilution and evaporative cooling.
Proactive provision reduces conflict with neighbours and businesses.
Mineral content can increase attractiveness vs chlorinated alternatives.
Objectives: Provide clean, stable water within a few metres of hives.
Design landing surfaces that prevent drowning.
Maintain year-round, not just during heat waves.
What Good Looks Like: Shallow tubs with stones/corks; slow drippers; shaded placement near apiaries.
Light mineral pinch (sea salt or aquarium salts) to increase attractiveness.
Routine top-ups and algae control without harmful chemicals.
Step-by-Step: 1) Choose container: shallow, broad surface with textured landings.
2) Place upwind of hives if possible to catch odour plumes; add shade.
3) Add floats (corks/pebbles) and a pinch of minerals; avoid strong scents.
4) Maintain: top up every 1–3 days in heat; scrub slime as needed; rotate containers to keep biofilm low.
5) Monitor: if bees still choose neighbour pools, adjust placement and mineral content.
Seasonality & Climate: Heat waves drive heavy demand; winter access may still be used on mild days.
Urban microclimates evaporate tubs quickly — increase capacity or drip-feed.
Data & Thresholds: Observe daily uptake; if dry by mid-day, add capacity.
Track neighbour feedback: zero pool visits is the target.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Bees on chlorinated pool -> Increase mineralisation slightly; move water source earlier in the flight path; add shade.
Symptom: Drowning -> Add more floats and rough surfaces; lower water depth.
Symptom: Algae/scum -> Increase cleaning rotation; consider moving to partial shade.
Common Pitfalls: Providing water only after complaints start.
Deep buckets without landings causing drownings.
Tools & Techniques: Corks/pebbles, drip irrigation timers, livestock troughs with floats.
Simple conductivity/total dissolved solids (TDS) meter to standardise mineral pinch.
Safety & Compliance: Secure tubs to avoid trip hazards; avoid mosquito breeding by flow or frequent refresh.
Do not add chemicals that could harm bees or violate site rules.
Field Checklist: Floats in place; mineral pinch logged.
Communications: Share a neighbour card explaining your on-site water plan.
